content.description:
This route is easily visible from the road and is the kind that makes you stop and say, "Holy cow, what's that?" This clean left facing dihedral houses a thin finger crack with a tricky start. It's a great option for rainy days, as it stays dry even in a downpour.

Watch out for poison ivy at the anchors!
content.protection: Finger-sized cams. The largest piece you'd be able to get might be a .75 camalot. Two-bolt anchor.
content.location: The large, very obvious left facing corner with finger crack.

content.description: Climbs a line of pockets just to the right of South Side of the Sky. Sees almost no traffic, so it is pretty sandy and licheny...
content.location: Just to the right of South Side of the Sky.

content.description: A no-feet start leads to less than vertical climbing on plates and edges.  At the 4th bolt the route turns vertical and finishes in a chimney as the holds get smaller and greasier.  Remember this is not a gym climb and stem or chimney your way to a fun no-hands anchor clip.
content.protection: 7 Bolts.  2 bolt anchor with cold shuts.
content.location: The is the first complete route on the left side of the crag.  There is an unfinished route (2 bolts) to the left and a trad line to the right that finishes at the same anchors.
